speaker: Clinician
text: Okay, Rina, let me recap what we just did: the tiny rod we slid into your left arm releases 68 micrograms of etonogestrel per day, enough to block ovulation for three solid years, and it’s already working within seven days.

speaker: Clinician
text: You might spot or get unpredictable bleeding the first few months; that’s normal, just track it in the phone app I loaded, and if cramps flare, stick with up to 600 mg ibuprofen every six hours, food in your stomach first.

speaker: Clinician
text: Because you’re couch-surfing, I tucked an extra gauze pack and the wallet card into your backpack—could you read back the removal date and the number to call if the skin turns hot, bright red, or starts oozing?

speaker: Patient
text: Uh, I’m sorry, I already, um, lost that little card somewhere between my cousin’s sofa and the shelter locker. The bandage looks kinda yellow at the edge, and the drugstore said my ibuprofen refill is maxed out, so I didn’t pick any up.

speaker: Clinician
text: No worries—I wrote the 19 July 2026 removal date on your arm with a skin-safe marker; snap a photo before it fades. The edge stain sounds like dried iodine, but if warmth spreads or you see pus, come in; we’ll swap antibiotics—nothing penicillin-based.

speaker: Clinician
text: About ibuprofen, the pharmacy limit only blocks prescription coupons; over-the-counter bottles run eight bucks, so grab one when you can. Just keep it under 2,400 mg total per day and stop if your stomach burns or you notice black stools, okay?

speaker: Patient
text: That’s helpful, but, um, I honestly forget things unless they buzz at me; my phone died last week and I’m borrowing a charger nightly. If I miss those first seven safe days, could I still get pregnant, or does the rod cover me anyway right now?

speaker: Patient
text: Also, uh, I can’t remember the last time I bled—it was sometime before my friend’s birthday in April? The spot’s itchy today, and my sister freaked me out saying infections travel fast; do I need a different medicine since penicillin is off the table for me totally?
